ST. JAMES POWER STATION
(Cost of Fire Damages)


    1. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Prime Minister what was the total cost of the damages to the St. James Power Station caused by the fire which broke out on 9th May, 1961.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to answer this question.

    A survey of the fire damage to St. James Power Station is still in progress, and is being undertaken by the contractor's insurance company. The installation at St. James Power Station is still on trial and has not yet been taken over by the City Council.

    The contractor has full insurance cover for the plant and property and is entirely responsible for making good the damage to City Council property which at present is estimated at $45,000.

    Inche Mohd. Ali(In Malay): Mr Speaker, could the Department concerned say when the damage to the St. James Power Station will be put right?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I take it the hon. Member means the Parliamentary Secretary and not the Department. We are not dealing with departments in this Assembly.

STREET LIGHTING IN ALSAGOFF ESTATE


    2. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Prime Minister when will kampong street lights be installed in all the "lorongs" from Lorong Marzuki to Jalan Sentosa and in the other unlighted parts in Alsagoff Estate.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    Kampong street lighting schemes are being systematically introduced throughout the Island according to priorities based upon population density and availability of electricity.

    In the area Paya Lebar to Jalan Alsagoff, street lighting was installed last year. In the area Jalan Alsagoff to Jalan Eunos, known as the Malay Farm, a proposal to light five streets at a cost of $15,000 has been submitted for consideration of the Planning Development Committee. The five streets are Jalan Betek, Jalan Tebu, Jalan Penggaga, Jalan Bayam, and Jalan Ubi. Proposals for the area Jalan Eunos to Jalan Sentosa will have to take their place alongside other proposals under the kampong lighting scheme. These particular areas have the added complication of being private property.

    Inche Mohd. Ali(In Malay): Mr Speaker, could the Parliamentary Secretary say whether street lighting could be installed in the area from Lorong Marzuki to Jalan Sentosa, which is considered to be private property?

Column: 1460



    Mr Chan Sun Wing: The answer is yes, but it will depend on the estimated cost.

    Inche Mohd. Ali(In Malay): Could the Parliamentary Secretary say whether street lighting facilities could be installed this year for the areas mentioned?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: Action will be taken to put up an estimated cost for lighting those streets, and we hope to do our best.

COMMON MARKET
(Statement on Talks with Federation of Malaya Government)


    3. Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat asked the Minister for Finance whether he will make a statement on the progress made in the talks with the Federation of Malaya Government on the Common Market.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposal to establish a Common Market arrangement in respect of a limited number of commodities produced either in the Federation or Singapore was first mooted by the Singapore Government in September 1959. As a result of subsequent discussions both at official and ministerial levels, the two Governments agreed to form a Joint Committee of Officials to discuss the proposal submitted by the Singapore Government for the establishment of a Common Market.

    Three meetings of the Joint Committee of Officials were held between 10th June, 1960, and 25th August, 1960. In the course of these meetings, the officials of the Federation Government sought elucidation on certain points, and both sides examined in detail the implications of the proposal. After the conclusion of the first series of meetings, the Federation representative asked for time to consider these proposals. It is hoped that talks on this question will be held shortly between Ministers of the Governments of Singapore and the Federation.

Column: 1461



    Dato Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister not agree that there has been no progress at all, and that in view of the Federation Government's attitude it would be better to drop the whole matter?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I do not agree that no progress has been made, Mr Speaker, Sir. May I remind the hon. Member that in the case of the European Common Market, it took nearly ten years before the proposals were finally put into shape? I see absolutely no cause for pessimism in regard to this scheme that we propose.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Would the Minister then give an indication whether the talks will be successful, since there have been no talks from August 1960?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member for Cairnhill is asking for an assurance which, in the nature of things, just cannot be given. But I would say that we are trying our best. The next step - and it is a significant advance - will be that discussions will be held at a higher level, that is to say, it has progressed from discussions between officials on purely technical matters to discussions between Ministers where the wider implications can be examined.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have not asked for an assurance. I have asked for an indication. Will the Minister please give an indication whether the talks are going to be successful?

    Mr Speaker: The Minister probably is not a pessimist.

PULAU BRANI COMMUNITY CENTRE
(Opening Date)

A. R. T. I. S.
(Number involved and detained)


    6. Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat asked the Minister for Home Affairs to state the number of persons involved in the "Artis" Affair who are now under detention.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of persons involved in the "Artis" Affair who are now under detention is 14.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: The answer is obvious; otherwise they would not have been released.

SERVICES OF POLICE OFFICERS EMPLOYED FOR PRIVATE
PURPOSES


    8. Mr Thio Chan Bee asked the Minister for Home Affairs, with reference to Government Gazette Notification No. 993 dated 12th May, 1961, prescribing the rates for the services of police officers employed for private purposes, if he will explain the circumstances under which he would allow such police officers to be so employed.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the circumstances under which the services of police officers would be approved for employment for private purposes include

    (a) circumstances of serious potential danger to persons or property which cannot otherwise reasonably be avoided for which there is sufficient justification for precautions but not sufficient to warrant depriving the public of the services of a trained guard and escort police officer without compensation to Government. For example, the guarding of a potential kidnap victim or of valuable property at a function to which large numbers of the public may have admission;

    (b) circumstances in which a crime might be committed on private premises to which large numbers of the public may have admission. For example, betting, gambling or pick-pocketing at the Singapore Turf Club meetings;

    (c) circumstances in which inconvenience might be caused to large numbers of the public by reason of traffic congestion at a private function or in its vicinity. For example, traffic control at large private functions or at the Singapore Turf Club;

    (d) circumstances in which valuables, bullion, pay-packets, etc, are transferred in public or stored in premises.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker. Sir, does the Minister realise that the morale of high-ranking police officers would be adversely affected if they are treated like mercenaries liable to obey new masters with changing situations?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first point is that the question does not arise. The second point is that I am not aware of the fear the Member has expressed.

    Mr Speaker: In any event, it is a matter of opinion. It is out of order. Is there any other supplementary question?

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Yes.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Thio.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Could the Minister assure us that there is a sufficient supply of police officers so that Government could afford to release them for these purposes?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware of any shortage of supply.

TRANSPORT FACILITIES FOR SCHOOL CHILDREN IN BLAKANG
MATI AND PULAU BRANI


    9. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Minister for Education what steps have been taken to overcome the transport difficulty of school-children in Blakang Mati and Pulau Brani who attend schools in Singapore.

Column: 1466



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, on 12th October, 1960, the Ketua of Telok Saga, Pulau Brani, wrote to the Minister informing him that, owing to a change in ferry schedules, children from Pulau Brani and Pulau Blakang Mati attending morning session schools in Singapore were unable to reach school in time. The Ministry took the matter up with the General Officer Commanding, Singapore Base District. Through the good offices of the latter, the War Department agreed to bring forward the RCL ferry timings in the mornings leaving Pulau Brani at 6.25 a.m. and Pulau Blakang Mati at 6.35 a.m. for Jardine Steps with effect from 21st November, 1960.

    Coincidentally, since notice of this question was received from the hon. Member for the Southern Islands, the Minister received a further petition dated 18th May, 1961, on this matter. This petition, purporting to have been signed by 75 residents of Pulau Brani, seeks the Ministry's assistance to get the Army authorities to revert the ferry service back to pre-October 1960 schedules. The Ministry is looking into this matter now and hopes to resolve it to the satisfaction of all concerned, as soon as possible.

    11. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that the new Malay school at Pulau Sakijang Pelepah has been closed for a long period, the reasons therefor, and when will it be reopened.

On the hill slope overlooking the school are some very large granite boulders which are considered a source of danger to the school. It is not advisable, therefore, for the school to start until these boulders have been removed. In Gazette Notification 852 dated 21st April, 1961, a tender was accepted for the removal of the boulders. It is hoped that the school will open by July 1961.

TOA PAYOH HOUSING SCHEME

Mr Thio Chan Bee asked the Minister for National Development to explain his plans regarding the Toa Payoh Housing Scheme; where and how will he resettle the displaced residents of Toa Payoh, the terms of compensation and the conditions for alternative accommodation; whether there will be alternative employment for those who will lose their means of livelihood because of the enforced removal; and whether he is aware of the general dissatisfaction among those affected by the proposed scheme in Ah Hood Road and Boon Teck Road, and what steps he proposes to take to remove their grievances.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Mr Speaker, Sir, briefly the Toa Payoh Housing Scheme envisages the development of a satellite town in about 600 acres of land in the Toa Payoh area. This is a scheme of considerable magnitude, and will have to be planned for implementation in stages; when completed, the scheme will provide a total of some 50,000 units, which will house a total of about 300,000 persons.

    There are at the moment about 2,000 to 3,000 families living on the land required for the scheme, and the Housing Board will make every effort to resettle these families in as equitable a manner as possible. Those who are genuine farmers will be given suitable compensation for everything they own or have put into the land, in accordance with the schedule of approved rates. In addition.

TOA PAYOH HOUSING SCHEME


    Mr Speaker: Back to questions. Question No. 12* - Mr Tan Kia Gan.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Those who are not farmers will be given three choices. If they wish to find alternative accommodation on their own, they will be paid compensation for any improvements they have put into the land in accordance with the schedule of approved rates. If they wish to be rehoused by the Housing Board, they will either be given one of the low-cost one-room units now under construction at Kim Keat Road and St. Michael's Estate at rentals of $20 p.m., or any other type of Housing Board accommodation, but they will not be paid any compensation for moving out. Lastly, they can choose to be resettled in one of the resettlement areas, where they will be given a small lot with a free house; they will also be paid compensation where appropriate for any improvements they own on the present land.

    Sir, I am, of course, aware that resettlement is a difficult problem and that the persons resettled will experience some initial inconvenience and, in some cases, perhaps some temporary difficulties. It is not expected that cases will arise of persons having to lose their present means of livelihood.     The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am pleased to take this responsibility upon myself for this. I regret to say that through an oversight in Gazette notification the original Ordinance was allowed to lapse.

    Sir, it is not my purpose here to apportion the blame between the S.A.G.'s Chambers and the Ministry of Home Affairs who are supposed to keep tabs on these things. But unfortunately arising out of the oversight, the matter was referred whether or not it was necessary, or whether or not it would make any difference in the long run to have the Ordinance continue in force. A lengthy debate took place with the Police who convinced me, as the then Acting Minister for Home Affairs, that the Bill should continue. I then gave instructions that, instead of a yearly renewal, a Bill should be prepared to allow the Ordinance to continue in force for a period of five years, and the matter could be reconsidered by a subsequent Assembly. When the Bill was prepared, the Minister for Home Affairs had come back and I personally lost touch with the matter. Subsequently, it was introduced not as a new Bill for a period of five years, which it is now our intention to move, but one which, as the Member for Farrer Park had pointed out, attempted to continue in existence a Bill which, technically, had lapsed by a failure to print a Gazette notification. The matter has now been put right. I do not know whether it is of advantage to pass any castigating remarks on either the Crown Counsel or the junior clerical officers who should have seen to this matter. However, I am assured that everybody did, in fact, do his duty, but the reference book which is turned up day by day to see what lapses and what needs to be renewed was unfortunately not turned up in this particular case in time. It was discovered a few days after it had lapsed. I must say this on behalf of the permanent officials of the Government - that the discovery was made within three days of the lapsing, and the length of time between the lapse and the introduction of the Bill does not indicate that it was forgotten for that long period of time, but it does indicate that a debate was going on whether a Bill of that nature should be

reintroduced. As I have said, we have decided that the Bill should continue, instead of a yearly renewal. It has a certain deterrent effect and should continue for the rest of the life of this Assembly.

    Question put, and agreed to.
